{{globalize|date=August 2011}} {{Discrimination sidebar}} '''Height discrimination''' (also known as '''heightism''') is [[prejudice]] or [[discrimination]] against individuals based on [[Human height|height]]. In principle, it refers to discriminatory treatment against individuals whose height is not within the normal acceptable range of height in a population. Height discrimination is most common against shorter than average men and is generally accepted and ignored.<ref name="judgecable">{{cite journal | last1 = Judge | first1 = A. T. | last2 = Cable | first2 = D. M. | year = 2004 | title = The Effect of Physical Height on Workplace Success and Income: Preliminary Test of a Theoretical Model | url = http://www.timothy-judge.com/Height%20paper--JAP%20published.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Journal of Applied Psychology | volume = 89 | issue = 3| pages = 428–441 | doi=10.1037/0021-9010.89.3.428 | pmid=15161403}}</ref><ref name="PPS">{{cite journal | last1 = Persico | first1 = Nicola | last2 = Postlewaite | first2 = Andrew | last3 = Silverman | first3 = Dan | year = 2004 | title = The Effect of Adolescent Experience on Labor Market Outcomes: The Case of Height | url = http://economics.sas.upenn.edu/~apostlew/paper/pdf/short.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Journal of Political Economy | volume = 112 | issue = 5| pages = 1019–53 | doi=10.1086/422566}}</ref> Some tall women have resorted to high dosages of oestrogen to reduce their height.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Radivojevic|first=U.|last2=Thibaud|first2=E.|last3=Samara-Boustani|first3=D.|last4=Duflos|first4=C.|last5=Polak|first5=M.|date=2006-04-01|title=Effects of growth reduction therapy using high-dose 17β-estradiol in 26 constitutionally tall girls|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1365-2265.2006.02485.x/abstract|journal=Clinical Endocrinology|language=en|volume=64|issue=4|pages=423–428|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2265.2006.02485.x|issn=1365-2265}}</ref>
Research indicates that the human brain uses height as a measurement to determine social status and fitness. The brain automatically associates physical size with leadership potential, power, strength and intelligence, an effect which has been discovered in infants as young as 10 months old. Evolutionary psychologists theorise that this is due to height indicating that the individual had been better fed, indicating higher social status and thus resources available to them, as well as indicating general health and physical strength, the latter of which can be useful in asserting dominance. The automatic association between height and the aforementioned traits has also been found to be much stronger when it comes to assessing men than women.<ref>Nancy Blaker, Irene Rompa, Inge Dessing, Anne Vriend, Channah Herschberg, Mark van Vugt, (2013) [http://professormarkvanvugt.com/images/files/heighlteadeshipGPIR.pdf "The height leadership advantage in men and women: Testing evolutionary psychology predictions about the perceptions of tall leaders"], DOI: 10.1177/1368430212437211, accessed 05/12/17</ref><ref>Stulp G., Buunk A. P., Verhulst S. and Pollet T. V, (2015), [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4342156/ "Human height is positively related to interpersonal dominance in dyadic interactions"], PLoS ONE 10, e0117860 10.1371/journal.pone.0117860, accessed 05/12/17</ref><ref>Joey Cheng, Jessica Tracy, Cameron Anderson, (2014) [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=6sx8BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA123&lpg=PA123&dq=height+and+social+status&source=bl&ots=FpEtA-Hep_&sig=6apS3YFWESxMH5UqF7mSMdZIYms&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiKr_PDkNvXAhVsIsAKHbnQDss4FBDoAQgvMAE#v=onepage&q=height%20and%20social%20status&f=true "The Psychology of Social Status"], c. 6, p. 123</ref>
==Origin of the term== The term ''height bigot'' was first used on the Mary Tyler Moore episode 7 of season 1 in October 1970. Mary is asked out by a charming, intelligent but very short man. Despite having a good time with him on a date she’s apprehensive about going out with him again because of his height. She declares herself a “height bigot” to her friend Rhoda.
The term ''heightism'' was coined by sociologist Saul Feldman in a paper titled "The presentation of shortness in everyday life—height and heightism in American society: Toward a sociology of stature", presented at the meeting of the [[American Sociological Association]] in 1971.<ref>Feldman, Saul. "The presentation of shortness in everyday life—height and heightism in American society: Toward a sociology of stature Paper". Presented at the meeting of the [[American Sociological Association]]. [[Chicago, Il]]. 1971.</ref><ref>heightism, n." [[OED Online]]. June 2003. [[Oxford University Press]]. September 2006.</ref> ''Heightism'' was included in the ''[[Second Barnhart Dictionary of New English]]'' (1971)<ref>{{cite journal | last = Shapiro | first = Fred R. | authorlink = Fred R. Shapiro | date = Spring 1985 | title = Historical Notes on the Vocabulary of the Women's Movement | journal = [[American Speech]] | volume = 60 | issue = 1 | pages = 14 | publisher = Duke University Press | jstor = 454643 }}</ref> and popularized{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} by ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine in a 1971 article on Feldman's paper.<ref>{{cite journal |date=4 October 1971 |title= Heightism.(Behavior) |journal= [[Time (magazine)|Time]] |publisher= [[Time, Inc.]] |volume= 98 |issue= 14 |pages= 82 }}</ref>
The word is an example of ''Time'' magazine's habit of supplying new words through "unusual use of affixes",<ref>{{cite journal |title=The Vocabulary of Time Magazine Revisited |jstor=454478 |doi=10.2307/454478 |first=Norris |last=Yates |journal=American Speech |volume=56 |issue=1 |date=Spring 1981 |publisher=[[Duke University Press]] |pages=55–60 }}</ref> although ''Time'' itself objected to the term's inclusion in the 1991 ''Random Webster's College Dictionary'', citing it as an example of the dictionary "straining ... to avoid giving offense, except to good usage" and "[lending] authority to scores of questionable usages, many of them tinged with [[politically correct]] views."<ref>{{cite journal |date=June 24, 1991 |title= Defining womyn (and others): Random House's new dictionary is gender neutral, politically correct - and an English-lover's disappointment |journal= [[Time (magazine)|Time]] |publisher= [[Time, Inc.]] |volume= 137 |issue= 25 |pages= 51 |last=Birnbaum |first=Jesse }}</ref>
The term ''heightism'' can also be seen as an example of the increase in popular usage of phrases, particularly those relating to prejudice and discrimination, patterned after that of the word ''[[sexism]].''<ref>{{cite journal | last = Shapiro | first = Fred R. | authorlink = Fred R. Shapiro | date = Spring 1985 | title = Historical Notes on the Vocabulary of the Women's Movement | journal = [[American Speech]] | volume = 60 | issue = 1 | pages = 8 | publisher = Duke University Press | jstor = 454643 }}</ref>
==Height and social discrimination==
===Employment wage and social experience discrimination===
A research paper published in the Journal of Applied Psychology showed that height is strongly related to success for men. It showed that increase in height for men corresponds to increase in income after controlling for other social psychological variables like age and weight.<ref name="judgecable"/> Economists [[Nicola Persico]], Andrew Postlewaite and Dan Silverman explained the "height premium" and found that "a 1.8-percent increase in wages accompanies every additional inch of height". They also found that men's wages as adults could be linked to their height at age 16. The researchers found that on an average an increase in height by one inch at age 16 increased male adult wages by 2.6 percent. This is equal to increase of approximately $850 in 1996 annual earnings. In other words, the height and corresponding social experiences of taller male adolescent at age 16 would likely translate to higher wage in later adulthood as compared to shorter male adolescent.<ref name="PPS"/>
As with all correlations, there may be other factors at work. For example, several epidemiological studies have shown a statistically significant positive correlation between [[height and intelligence]] in human populations. However, this correlation, though statistically significant, is generally weak and does not imply that variations in stature have a direct effect on cognitive ability. Though significant correlations have been found in early and late childhood in both developed and developing countries, in adults, changes in environment and [[social status]] reduce the strength of this correlation.<ref name="Teasdale1989">{{cite journal |author1=Teasdale T. W. |author2=Srensen T. I. A. |author3=Owen D. R. | year = 1989 | title = Fall in association of height with intelligence and educational level | url = | journal = British Medical Journal | volume = 298 | issue = 6683| pages = 1292–1293 | doi = 10.1136/bmj.298.6683.1292 | pmid = 2500201 | pmc = 1836522 }}</ref>
Recent findings suggest that height discrimination occurs most often against racial minorities. A 2007 study found that African-Americans reported higher weight and height related discrimination. This discrimination was even higher in female employees.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Roehling|first=Mark V.|last2=Roehling|first2=Patricia V.|last3=Pichler|first3=Shaun|date=2007-10-01|title=The relationship between body weight and perceived weight-related employment discrimination: The role of sex and race|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0001879107000437|journal=Journal of Vocational Behavior|volume=71|issue=2|pages=300–318|doi=10.1016/j.jvb.2007.04.008}}</ref>
In 2017, attourney and author lawyer Tanya Osensky published ''[https://www.amazon.com/Shortchanged-Height-Discrimination-Strategies-Social/dp/1512601438 Shortchanged: Height Discrimination and Strategies for Social Change]''.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/1512601438/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_ep_dp_NztSBbASX6R6P|title=Shortchanged: Height Discrimination and Strategies for Social Change|last=results|first=search|date=2017-10-03|publisher=ForeEdge|isbn=9781512601435|language=English}}</ref> The book exposes the cultural, medical, and occupational issues that short people face, which are often deemed unimportant and disregarded. Osensky challenges heightism by disclosing some beneficial aspects of shortness and suggesting avenues of activism and change.
===In business=== Some jobs do require or at least favor tall people, including some [[manual labor]] jobs, law enforcement, most [[professional sports]], flight attendants, and fashion modeling. US Military pilots have to be 63 to 79 inches (160 to 200 cm) tall with a sitting height of {{convert|34|to|40|in|cm}}.<ref name="AFROTC">{{cite web|url=http://www.afrotc.com/admissions/medicalReq.php|title=U.S. Air Force ROTC despite statistical and physical evidence to support the proposition that short people consistently have reduced reaction times.: Admissions requirements|website=afrotc.com|accessdate=22 October 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061008211834/http://www.afrotc.com/admissions/medicalReq.php|archivedate=8 October 2006|df=}}</ref> These exceptions noted, in the great majority of cases a person’s height would not seem to have an effect on how well they are able to perform their job. Nevertheless, studies have shown that short people are paid less than taller people, with disparities similar in magnitude to the race and gender gaps.<ref name="Why tall people make more money">{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/Careers/02/02/cb.tall.people/index.html|title=Why tall people make more money - CNN.com|first=By Meg Donohue |last=CareerBuilder.com|website=www.cnn.com|accessdate=22 October 2017}}</ref>
Surveys have uncovered that less than 3% of [[Chief executive officer|CEOs]] were below {{height|ft=5|in=7}} in height. 90% of CEOs are of above average height.<ref name="Jonathan Rauch">[http://www.jonathanrauch.com/jrauch_articles/height_discrimination_short_guys_finish_last/index.html "Short Guys Finish Last" The world's most enduring form of discrimination. The Economist, 23 December 1995].</ref>
In 2018, market researcher Seth Ulinski published ''[http://a.co/d/e7JshIA Amazing Heights: How Short Men Stand Tall]''.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07FQPLMPR/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_ep_dp_KytSBbADZ5V9Y|title=Amazing Heights: How Short Men Stand Tall|last=Ulinski|first=Seth|language=English}}</ref> The book highlights that through technology and an entrepreneurial mindset, members of the "short guy fraternity" are able to blaze their own paths - bypassing potential glass ceilings and pay gaps. For example, short guy fraternity members include: Amazon founder and CEO Jeff Bezos (5'7<nowiki>''</nowiki>), Facebook founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg (5'7<nowiki>''</nowiki>) and Google co-founder and Alphabet President Sergey Brin (5'8<nowiki>''</nowiki>). With an estimated net worth of over $150 billion,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/jeff-bezos-net-worth-life-spending-2018-8|title=Jeff Bezos is the richest person alive — here's how he makes and spends his billions|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-09-30}}</ref> Bezos is ranked as the richest person in the world, while Zuckerberg and Brin consistently rank in the top 20.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/richest-people-world-billionaires-list-2017-11|title=These are the 50 richest people in the world right now|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-09-30}}</ref>
===Dating and marriage=== Heightism is also a factor in dating preferences. For some people, height is a [[Physical attractiveness#Height|noteworthy factor in sexual attractiveness]].
The greater reproductive success of taller men is attested to by studies indicating that taller men are more likely to be married and to have more children, except in societies with severe sex imbalances caused by war.<ref name="DontWant">[http://jrscience.wcp.muohio.edu/Research/HumanNatureProgArticles/dontwantnoshortshortmanFI.html Miami University of Ohio: “Don’t Want No Short, Short Man: The Study Of Height, Power, and Mate Selection”].</ref> However, more recent research has drawn this theory into question, finding no correlation between height and offspring count.<ref name="correlate">[http://www.epjournal.net/filestore/EP06369385.pdf "Physique Correlates with Reproductive Success in an Archival Sample of Delinquent Youth"].</ref> Moreover, research on leg length and [[Physical attractiveness#Leg-to-body ratio|leg-to-body ratio]] conflicts with the notion that there is a distinct preference for taller mates. A 2008 study found that both extremes, tall and short, reduced attractiveness, and a 2006 study found that a lower leg-to-body ratio in men and higher leg-to-body ratio in women increased aesthetic appeal.<ref name="legLength">[https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:Ez5uazVNELMJ:commonsenseatheism.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/Sorokowski-Adaptive-preferences-for-leg-length-in-a-potential-partner.pdf+height+and+occupational+success+evolutionary&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESg6EYN1yttQPQbBwLLz8tPj-mBx6kZUVyHs6o1vPeHRQKqxaJyQI7mlfiw1SQ-gMO1OLj_DI5ldyCJCriyl2qef_gWiJm6OWjaO4s-gCR15YYTbHaigK5jHbzvAHGoqD474ceF-&sig=AHIEtbSIDsqspZnNj5-F3bF5sqoWVnVeTQ&pli=1: "Adaptive Preferences for Leg Length in a Potential Partner"].</ref><ref name="aAppeal">[https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:Ez5uazVNELMJ:commonsenseatheism.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/Sorokowski-Adaptive-preferences-for-leg-length-in-a-potential-partner.pdf+height+and+occupational+success+evolutionary&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESg6EYN1yttQPQbBwLLz8tPj-mBx6kZUVyHs6o1vPeHRQKqxaJyQI7mlfiw1SQ-gMO1OLj_DI5ldyCJCriyl2qef_gWiJm6OWjaO4s-gCR15YYTbHaigK5jHbzvAHGoqD474ceF-&sig=AHIEtbSIDsqspZnNj5-F3bF5sqoWVnVeTQ&pli=1: "The leg-to-body ratio as a human aesthetic criterion"].</ref> Biologically, from an evolutionary perspective, these findings are consistent with data relating [[Human height#Height and (physiological and psychological) health|height to human health]]. Therefore, a biological or, more specifically, an evolutionary argument for the preference of a taller mate is questionable, lacking definitive evidence. Nonetheless, research by [[Dan Ariely]] found that American women exhibit a marked preference for dating taller men, and that for shorter men to be judged attractive by women, they must earn substantially more money than taller men.<ref>"Ariely found that a 5'4" man would need to make $229,000 more than a 6' man to have equal appeal; a 5'6" man would need $183,000 more; a 5'10" man would need $32,000 more." [[Lori Gottlieb]] (2010). ''Marry Him: The Case for Settling for Mr. Good Enough''. Penguin, {{ISBN|9781101185209}} p. 239</ref>
A 2012 study found that both men and women are willing to excuse height differences by using a trade-off approach. Men may compensate 1.3 BMI units with a 1 percent higher wage than their wife. Women may compensate 2 BMI units with an additional year of higher education.<ref name="Sohn 110–124">{{Cite journal|last=Sohn|first=Kitae|date=2015-07-01|title=The value of male height in the marriage market|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1570677X15000398|journal=Economics & Human Biology|volume=18|pages=110–124|doi=10.1016/j.ehb.2015.05.004}}</ref> Furthermore, a 2015 study found that both men and women receive benefits for having a tall spouse. The husband's gains include beauty that results from his wife's positive attributes that are correlated with her height such as education. The wife on the other hand looks for a tall husband due to them generating higher earnings.<ref name="Sohn 110–124"/>
Nonetheless, on a cultural level in [[Post-industrial society]], a sociological relationship between height and perceived attractiveness exists. This cultural characteristic, while applicable to the modernized world, is not a transcendental human quality.<ref name="hadza">[http://eprints.lse.ac.uk/24375/1/How_universal_are_human_mate_choices_%28LSERO%29.pdf: "How universal are human mate choices? Size doesn’t matter when Hadza foragers are choosing a mate"].</ref> Quantitative studies of woman-for-men [[personal advertisement]]s have shown strong preference for tall men, with a large percentage indicating that a man significantly below average height was unacceptable.<ref name="ShortSupport3">[http://www.shortsupport.org/Research/personals.html Short Persons Support: “Personals Analyzer”].</ref> A study produced by the Universities of Groningen and Valencia, has found that men who felt most anxious about attractive, physically dominant, and socially powerful rivals, were less jealous, the taller they were themselves.<ref name="Nature.com">[http://blogs.nature.com/news/thegreatbeyond/2008/03/short_men_are_the_jealous_type.html Short men are the jealous type - March 13, 2008"].</ref> The study also found that women were most jealous of others' [[physical attractiveness]], but women of medium height were the least jealous.<ref name="The New Scientist">[https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg19726475.200-your-height-dictates-how-jealousy-strikes.html Your height dictates how jealousy strikes"].</ref> The report, produced by Dutch and Spanish researchers, stated that because average height women tend to be the most fertile and healthy, they would be less likely to feel threatened by women with those similar features.<ref name="BBC">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/7291366.stm Short men 'are the most jealous'"].</ref>
===In the media=== In the [[Mass media|media]], heightism can take the form of making fun of people whose height is out of the normal range in ways that would be unseemly if directed at [[skin color]] or [[weight]]. An example is [[Kevin Connolly (actor)|Kevin Connolly]]'s portrayal of Eric "E" Murphy in [[HBO]]'s television series [[Entourage (U.S. TV series)|Entourage]] (Connolly is {{convert|5|ft|5|in|abbr=on|disp=or}})<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0175305/bio Kevin Connolly (I) - Biography<!--Bot-generated title-->].</ref>
Similarly, shorter men are often denied leading roles. Although some famous cinema actors such as [[Alan Ladd]] {{convert|5|ft|5|in|m|abbr=on}} have been short in real life, in their fictional depictions they have been presented as taller. There have also been cases of very tall actors encountering problems in Hollywood. [[Dolph Lundgren]] and [[Armie Hammer]], both standing about {{convert|6|ft|4+1/2|in|m|sigfig=3|abbr=on}}, stated that they had lost jobs or were about to do so because of being too tall.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.celebheights.com/s/Dolph-Lundgren-22.html|title=Dolph Lundgren Height - How tall|website=www.celebheights.com|accessdate=22 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.celebheights.com/s/Armie-Hammer-47501.html|title=Armie Hammer Height|website=www.celebheights.com|accessdate=22 October 2017}}</ref>
In 1987 the [[BBC]] comedy series ''[[A Small Problem]]'' imagined a totalitarian society in which people under the height of {{convert|5|ft}} were systematically discriminated against. The program attracted considerable criticism and complaints which accused the writers of reinforcing prejudice and of using offensive terms; the writers responded that their intention had been to show all prejudice was stupid and that height was chosen randomly.<ref name="BBC Comedy guide">[http://www.bbc.co.uk/comedy/guide/articles/s/smallproblema_1299002875.shtml A Small Problem] in BBC Comedy Guide.</ref>
[[S&M Short and Male]], a documentary aired in 2008, demonstrated the obstacles and bigotry that short statured men face every day in life, love and work.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Movies/Reviews/S/S_M_Short_And_Male/2008/05/16/5585311-sun.html |title=CANOE - JAM! S&M: Short And Male: Short guys film rises to challenge |publisher=Jam.canoe.ca |date=2008-05-16 |accessdate=2013-08-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/MensHealthNews/story?id=8347950 |title=Short People Face Discrimination, Teasing and Lower Salaries - ABC News |publisher=Abcnews.go.com |date=2009-08-18 |accessdate=2013-08-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/news/story.html?id=abfc3842-dab7-4220-afab-6f9a1f3b0e04 |title=In short, stature's no joke, filmmaker argues |publisher=Canada.com |date=2008-05-11 |accessdate=2013-08-20}}</ref>
==Legislation== Currently, there is one state in the United States of America, [[Michigan]], that prohibits height discrimination.<ref name="Michigah">[http://www.michigan.gov/documents/act_453_elliott_larsen_8772_7.pdf Text] of the Elliot Larsen Civil Rights Act of 1976.</ref> There is pending legislation introduced by [[Massachusetts]] Representative [[Byron Rushing]] which would add Massachusetts to the list.<ref name="Massachusetts">[http://www.mass.gov/legis/bills/house/ht03pdf/ht03752.pdf Text (PDF)] of Massachusetts House bill 3752, 2006.</ref> Two municipalities currently prohibit height discrimination: [[Santa Cruz, California]]<ref name="Advocates">[http://www.genderadvocates.org/policy/Ordinances/Laws/Santa%20Cruz%20Ordinance.htm Chapter 9.83] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061105201654/http://www.genderadvocates.org/policy/Ordinances/Laws/Santa%20Cruz%20Ordinance.htm |date=2006-11-05 }} of the City of Santa Cruz code – "Prohibition against Discrimination", 1992.</ref> and [[San Francisco, California]].<ref name="NAAFA">[http://www.naafa.org/fatf/sf_height_weight.html Text] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061114214707/http://www.naafa.org/fatf/sf_height_weight.html |date=2006-11-14 }} of Compliance Guidelines To Prohibit Weight and Height Discrimination; San Francisco Administrative Code Chapters 12A, 12B and 12C and San Francisco Municipal/Police Code Article 33, 26 July 2001.</ref> The [[District of Columbia]] prohibits discrimination based on personal appearance.<ref name="DC">[http://ohr.dc.gov/ohr/cwp/view,a,3,q,491858,ohrNav,%7C30953%7C.asp Text] District of Columbia Human Rights Act.</ref> [[Ontario]], Canada prohibits height discrimination under the human rights code.<ref name="Ontario">[http://www.ohrc.on.ca/en/resources/Policies/PolicyHtWt/view Policy on height and weight requirements] Ontario, Canada Human Rights Code.</ref> [[Victoria, Australia]] prohibits discrimination based on physical features under the Equal Opportunity Act of 1995.<ref name="Victoria">[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/vic/consol_act/eoa1995250/index.html Text] Victoria, Australia Equal Opportunity Act of 1995.</ref>
Examples of successful legal battles pursued against height discrimination in the workplace include a 2002 case involving highly qualified applicants being turned down for jobs at a bank because they were considered too short;<ref name="Chinese">[http://www.cnn.com/2004/LAW/05/31/dorf.height.discrimination/index.html Chinese Height Discrimination Case].</ref> a 2005 Swedish case involving an unfair height requirement for employment implemented by [[Volvo]] car company;<ref name="Volvo">[https://archive.is/20120918124449/http://www.eiro.eurofound.eu.int/2005/11/inbrief/se0511102n.html Volvo Car Company Height requirement for employment].</ref> and a 1999 case involving a [[Kohler Company]] informal practice not to consider women who applied for jobs unless they were at least {{convert|5|ft|4|in|abbr=on}} tall.<ref name="Kohler">[http://www.dol.gov/opa/media/press/esa/archive/esa99268.htm Kohler Corp. Gender Discrimination Case].</ref> Height requirements for employment which are not a [[Bona fide occupational requirement|''bona fide'' occupational requirement]] are becoming less common.
==Height and suicide in men== A research report published in the [[American Journal of Psychiatry]] found a strong inverse association between height and suicide in Swedish men which may signify the importance of childhood exposure in the [[etiology]] of adult mental disorder or reflect stigmatization or discrimination encountered by short men in their adult lives. A record linkage study of the birth, conscription, mortality, family, and census register data of 1,299,177 Swedish men followed from age 18 to a maximum of age 49 was performed and it was found that a 5-cm (2-inch) increase in height was associated with a 9% decrease in suicide risk.<ref name=" Patrik K.E. Magnusson et al. ">[http://ajp.psychiatryonline.org/doi/pdf/10.1176/appi.ajp.162.7.1373 " Strong Inverse Association Between Height and Suicide in a Large Cohort of Swedish Men: Evidence of Early Life Origins of Suicidal Behavior? The American Journal of Psychiatry, July 2005].</ref>
